Description: Rim and body sherd with part of handle of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed black below; top of rim glazed; exterior: lip and handle zone reserved with band between; glazed below; black on handle roots; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type A2 (possibly)
Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer Identifies the sherd as possibly belonging to a Type 5C, Type 9A or Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. However, the curved junction below the rim is not typical of his Type 9B. Type 5C cups are the earliest South Ionian cups at Naukratis and are relatively rare at the site. Type 9A cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. Both of these cup types coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard's Ionian Cup Type A2 or B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. The number in Petrie's catalogue, 112, is written in ink on the exterior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXII, no. 112)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 650, no. 74)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 49, no. 34)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.125) (Phase 3)
